thread.title: New car buyers unwilling to pay for advanced safety features
thread.title_full: New car buyers unwilling to pay for advanced safety features - Chicago Tribune

author: Jenny King
title: New car buyers unwilling to pay for advanced safety features
text:
Traffic fatalities in the U.S. could be reduced by a third and billions of related dollars saved if new car buyers would be more willing to pay for driver assistance systems, according to a new study.
The study, conducted for the Motor & Equipment Manufacturers Association by The Boston Consulting Group, states that current advanced driver assistance technology has the potential to prevent 2.3 million crashes and save over $200 billion a year.
"Motor vehicle crashes cost the U.S. $910 billion, or $4,000 per vehicle each year," said Xavier Mosquet, who heads Boston Consulting's automotive practice in its Detroit office. "Advanced driver assistance systems available today could reduce this cost by around 30 percent and reduce fatalities by one-third."
Safety systems penetration is moving at only 2 to 5 percent a year, research says.
Lack of education about systems among consumers, regulators and decision-makers in the auto industry is one reason growth is so slow.
Another is consumer reluctance to pick up the tab for proven safety equipment like forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control and lane departure warning. Despite being the most popular features, only 7 percent of new car buyers were willing to pay for them in 2015.
Data shows drivers would be willing to spend a premium of $5,000 for an automated car, but they balk at the extra expense of proven and relatively affordable driver assistance systems, Mosquet said.

(Tribune wire reports) Mosquet said average consumer willingness to pay is 25 to 75 percent lower than current market prices for advanced driver assistance technology.
For example, a suggested retail price for combined adaptive cruise/forward collision warning/forward collision avoidance might be $1,500. Consumers said they would pay $470 for the same system, a difference of 69 percent.
Park assist, a $250 option that alerts drivers of objects behind them or in blind spots, is seen as more desirable than less glamorous technology. Buyers said they would consider paying $190 for it. Consumers said they would pay $170 for a $400 lane departure warning option.
The study sponsored by the manufacturers association projects driver assistance technology prices will fall as orders increase.
In the meantime, the industry needs to reconsider the way advanced safety features are offered, Mosquet said. Instead of being bundled in option packages, features should be available separately.
The European new car assessment program's five-star ratings on crashworthiness include assessments of adult protection, child protection, pedestrian protection and safety assist technologies.

While the U.S. assessment needs major updating, forcing advanced safety equipment on consumers is not an acceptable strategy, Mosquet said.
"If we mandated it today, we will have serious problems," he said.
